item.title: 'There wouldn't be any deal:' Krafton CEO appraises Unknown Worlds acquisition in court
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

November 19, 2025

4 Min Read

Image and artwork via Krafton

Krafton CEO Changhan 'CH' Kim claims the South Korean publisher would not have acquired Subnautica developer Unknown Worlds had he known studio co-founder and game director Charlie Cleveland allegedly intended to reduce his role post-buyout. 

Kim's remarks were made during the ongoing trial between ousted Unknown Worlds co-founders Charlie Cleveland, Max McGuire, and Ted Gill, which is taking place this week in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware. 

Cleveland, McGuire, and Gill wish to be reinstated at Unknown Worlds after being fired by Krafton earlier this year. The trio claim they were forced out by Krafton so the publisher could avoid paying a multi-million dollar earnout tied to the successful 2025 early access launch of Subnautica 2, which has been delayed until 2026. They also allege that Kim worked to seize control of the studio by forming a secret task force dubbed 'Project X' in an effort to protect his job. 

Krafton, however, claims the leadership team abandoned their posts. In a pre-trial brief filed by the conglomerate earlier this month (uploaded by Game Developer on Scribd), Krafton accused the former execs of becoming "absentee landlords" after purportedly downing tools and stealing confidential information on their way out of the door. 

Related:After seven years, the Epic Games Store enables gifting

Testifying in court on November 18, 2025, Kim stated that Krafton was unaware Cleveland and McGuire had stopped contributing to Subnautica 2. He also claimed both former execs were given the opportunity to return to their posts but rejected the offer, and that Cleveland specifically was determined to pursue unrelated movie projects. 

Notably, Kim repeatedly stated that Krafton would never have spent an initial $500 million on Unknown Worlds in 2021 had it known the leadership team would allegedly seek to abandon their posts.

"There wouldn't be any deal," replied Kim, when asked what would have happened if Cleveland had informed him before the acquisition that he wanted to stop making video games. 

"There wouldn't be any deal, I don't think," replied Kim, when asked what would have happened if Cleveland had informed him that, post-acquisition, he would play no part in the development of Subnautica 2. 

Finally, Kim was asked whether Krafton would have granted the trio operational control of Unknown Worlds had it known Cleveland and McGuire would allegedly abandon Subnautica 2. "The single purpose of Unknown Worlds is to make games. And if they are not making any games, I don't think—there is no meaning for them to have any operational control. I don't think I would have given it to them," he replied.

Related:Hypixel acquires Hytale back from Riot Games

"I believed that the fans would eventually get disappointed"

Kim also questioned why Krafton would now allow the former executives to return to their posts. "These are the people who rejected our proposal for them to return to their post. So why they would like to return now, and what are they going to do, I'm not sure about that," he continued. 

"And currently the development team is pretty stabilized, and they are working on the development in earnest. So I am concerned about if—about their potential return, if they do return. And, thirdly, the trust is, I think, already broken, so I don't think we're in a state that we can—we are or can be ready or can work with them again." 

As for whether Subnautica 2 was primed for a 2025 early access launch as the former leadership team claims, Kim said Krafton could probably have generated some sales had it pushed ahead with the original plan, but suggested the title lacks "freshness" in its current guise. 

"Because the fans already had a lot of expectations for the sequel, so there might be some sale that would occur initially," continued Kim. "But because of the lack of the content, the lack of freshness, I believed that the fans would eventually get disappointed. And if that is the case, then actually the future of the franchise would be greatly impacted, was what I was thinking."

Related:U.S. congressman calls out alleged AI usage in Call of Duty

Kim's testimony chimes with the below statement provided by Krafton when approached for comment on the trial:

"The trial is currently ongoing where we are making the case that the decisions we have made were all about ensuring the best possible experience for our players. As we have made clear—we were forced to make a change when the former leaders showed little interest in the development of Subnautica 2, which has always been our top priority," said a Krafton spokesperson. 

"Now, this trial comes down to plaintiffs asking to be restored to jobs they were not doing, said they had no interest in doing, and had previously declined requests that they come back and do those jobs. We look forward to continuing to present our evidence before the judge and are confident we will prevail and be allowed to continue our incredible progress."

The trial will last through November 19, 2025, after which both parties will submit post-trial briefings. A post-trial argument has been set for January 9, 2026. The court's decision will follow.
